content: First, if you prefer another email client, then go do it. Thunderbird is free, so there is no sense of lost revenue if you depart. If you want assistance, it may help if you post a screenshot of your problem, as I cannot duplicate it. Thank you.
creator: davidsk

content: I am confused. The purpose of the Oauth2 pass code is to automate the login process for you. This is not something Thunderbird is doing on its own, but following the established security process of the email provider. My suggestion is to let the process do its thing. If you still want to protect the accounts, I suggest adding a Primary Password to prevent others from signing in to Thunderbird.
creator: davidsk

content: As a followup, that pass code Yahoo gives you works ONLY on that one PC, so stealing it would accomplish nothing.
creator: davidsk

content:
Yahoo stated the change was required to improve security. They said nothing about it automating the process, that was a most unfortunate after the fact discovery. According to Yahoo, there is no way to use a third party email program with email addresses provided by Yahoo anymore without configuring the software to use oauth.

What would be the process for adding a password so other users of the same computer cannot log into my Thunderbird account?
creator: eric.nordin

content: click settings>privacy&security and tick the box for a primary password. BE CAREFUL that it is one you remember, as you will need to use it each time you start Thunderbird.
creator: davidsk

content: Thank you! That solved the problem. Don't know why I didn't see that option before myself. I really appreciate the help.
creator: eric.nordin

content: You are welcome. :)

content: Please post screenshot of incoming and outgoing server panes and I will attempt to assist. Thank you.

content: There is no such thing as a 'Mozilla Thunderbird sign in password'. Thunderbird is an application run on your device, so it does not provide email addresses, nor the service to transmit emails. But Thunderbird can be used with your existing email address and service provider to send, receive, sort and search your email messages. So you'd have to talk to your email provider about password recovery options.
creator: christ1

content: Ah, natuurlijk. Voor Thunderbird ligt het iets ingewikkelder, omdat sommige bestanden in het profiel niet compatibel kunnen zijn met eerdere versies. Over het algemeen wordt installatie van een eerdere versie over de bestaande versie heen daarom afgeraden; er wordt dan een nieuw profiel aangemaakt en dan lijkt het alsof alles verdwenen is. Dat is niet zo, en met wat geluk werkt het eerdere profiel ook nog, maar dit is geen garantie.
creator: markh2

content: First, make sure your incoming server is outlook.office365.com, port 993, SSL/TLS and Oauth2 (assuming IMAP), and that outgoing server is smtp.office365.com, port 587, STARTTLS, Oauth2.

content: You should have received an email from MS months ago that the account info was changing. Try this: - input: outlook.office365.com, port 993, SSL/TLS and Oauth2 (assuming IMAP) - output: smtp.office365.com, port 587, STARTTLS and Oauth2
creator: davidsk

content:
1. you cannot convert POP to IMAP, but you can create an IMAP account alongside it. if you want to close the POP account, you can create local folders and move the messages there prior to closing the POP account. It is also possible, after copying to local folders, to upload to the IMAP account, but that can be problematic and should be done in small groups and then checked afterwards.
  1. you cannot use an SMTP for one account with another account. Most email hosts will reject as spam. As an aside, you might investigate email settings for Swissmail and Freeler to determine why the emails are not being processed.
creator: davidsk

content: Ma gli alias sono indipendenti a livello di login? In altre parole, quando configurali ad esempio alias2@dominioB.it come alias, lo configuri per fare un login alias2@dominioB.it+password? Chiedo perch√© l'indirizzo della posta in uscita √® sempre quello con cui fai il login SMTP.
creator: @next

content:
next ha detto
Ma gli alias sono indipendenti a livello di login? In altre parole, quando configurali ad esempio alias2@dominioB.it come alias, lo configuri per fare un login alias2@dominioB.it+password? Chiedo perch√© l'indirizzo della posta in uscita √® sempre quello con cui fai il login SMTP.

No, gli alias sono tali proprio perch√® non sono account distinti, quindi il login avviene solo tramite l'account primario. Si tratta di una funzionalit√† che GMail gestisce senza problemi e non dipende dal login SMTP.

Probabilmente c'√® qualcosa che mi sfugge nella configurazione a monte perch√® su Thunderbird dovrebbe essere tutto ok. Far√≤ un nuovo controllo. Grazie comunque per il feedback.
creator: fabio.pratesi

content: Risolto... gli alias erano stati configurati a livello di account ma non nelle impostazioni di GMail, quindi il mittente non cambiava. Dopo averli aggiunti tutto funziona correttamente.
